awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Deglacial and Holocene Environmental Change in California's Headwaters:  Insights from High-Resolution Sedimentary Records from Mono Lake
awd_abstract_narration:
As droughts, floods, and wildfires increase in frequency, intensity, and devastation, new emphasis must be placed on understanding the climate system of the American West.  This project will study sediments from the Mono Basin, the most important water source for California.  Located in the eastern Sierra Nevada, Mono Lake is highly sensitive to changes in the amount of precipitation falling in the region. The project will develop well-dated lake data to compare with climate models for the last ~16,000 years to study the mechanisms that control environmental change.  In addition, the project will produce methodological improvements in sediment-dating techniques, produce virtual tours for the Flyover Country mobile phone app and develop educational materials for national park and community groups. The project also will use project datasets in hands-on STEM training for undergraduate and graduate students and high school teachers. 

Well-dated lake sediment cores provide one of the few terrestrial archives available to extend the record of climate change in the American West into the early Holocene and terminal Pleistocene. Interpretation of geochemical, sedimentological, and paleobiological proxy records from Mono Lake cores will provide continuous records of lake level and productivity that are tied to absolute lake levels available from paleo-shorelines. A sub-centennial-precision age model for the records will allow accurate and precise correlation of terrestrial climate conditions in the West to global records for the first time. This will shed light on the mechanisms controlling Western climate between the waning of the great continental ice sheets and the droughts and pluvials of the last 2000 years, which have been examined in detail in tree-ring records.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Mono Lake basin is one of the iconic scenic areas of the Sierra Nevada region, with glacially carved canyons, groves of tufa towers rising from the lake, thousands of migrating birds, and the chain of Mono Craters quietly trailing south from the lake shore. The long history of eruptions from the Mono Craters continues up to the last few hundred years and has been intensely interesting to scientists since the late nineteenth century, but the number and pattern of eruptions before the last 2000 years have been difficult to reconstruct. Building on the work of U.S. Geological Survey scientists who showed that the chemistry of mineral crystals in the Craters could connect them with volcanic ashes (tephras) preserved in sediments of the glacial-age lake, we have studied the chemistry of tephras and Craters from the end of the glacial period through the Holocene Epoch, the last ~15,000 years.

            We found that, while tephras preserved in the peat layers of Crooked Meadow south of the Lake are poorly preserved, several tephras interbedded with lake sediments in cores from Mono Lake itself could be chemically fingerprinted and correlated.  Most significantly, one thick, coarse tephra appears in both a shallow-water and a deep-water core, and can be traced to its likely source in the Mono Craters. Since volcanic tephras mark a single instant in geologic time, this provides a timeline that can be used to correlate across the basin. The age of the tephra from the deep-water core, ~13,000 years, extends the age-depth model of the shallow-water core, which previously couldn't be extended past 11,000 years ago. This is a particularly exciting time period, because Mono Lake experienced huge changes in lake level related to reorganization of the global climate system as the last of the continental ice sheets melted away. The lake rose and fell by as much as 100 meters through the deglacial period, before settling into fluctuations in the range of a few tens of meters around the current lake level at around 10,000 years ago.

            Along with other thinner tephras (too fine-grained for our chemical analysis) that can be correlated based on other characteristics, we now can trace changes from deep-water to shallow-water settings more precisely than with radiocarbon dates alone. Together with studies of the terrestrial vegetation from pollen preserved in the cores, changes in aquatic organisms such as diatoms and ostracods, and the chemistry of the mud itself, this gives us new insights into how Mono Lake and its basin were affected by changes in global and regional climate over the last 13,000 years.
